will.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: A meeting will be held next Tuesday at 3 p.m.
I hope they won’t be late.
Maybe by then you will have changed your mind.
will.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: used to show that someone is willing or ready to do something
will.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Dr Weir will see you now.
will.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: used to ask someone to do something
will.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: used to say what always happens in a particular situation or what is generally true
will.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: used like ‘can’ to show what is possible
will.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: This car will hold five people comfortably.
will.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: used to say that you think something is true
will.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: That will be Tim coming home now.
As you will have noticed, there are some gaps in the data.
will.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: used to give an order or to state a rule
will.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: You will do as I say.
Every employee will carry an identity card at all times.
will.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: used to offer something to someone or to invite them to do something
will.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: Will you have some more tea?
will.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: used to describe someone’s habits, especially when you think they are annoying
will.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: Trish will keep asking silly questions.
will.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: GRAMMAR: Choosing the right tense
will.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0]: You use will when talking about the future
I’m sure the party will be a big success
will.translation[0].note_box[0].items[1]: Usually will changes to would when reporting what someone said or thought
She said she was sure that the party would be a big success
will.translation[0].note_box[0].items[2]: If the event is still in the future, will is sometimes used, especially after the present perfect tense
Lots of people have said they will come to the party
will.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: determination to do something that you have decided to do, even if this is difficult
will.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: Even though she was in terrible pain, Mary never lost the will to live.
will.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: a legal document that says who you want your money and property to be given to after you die
will.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: Have you made a will yet?
the senator’s last will and testament
My grandfather left me some money in his will.
will.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: what someone wants to happen in a particular situation
will.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: He accused her of trying to impose her will on others.
Collier claims the police forced him to sign a confession against his will.
will.translation[1].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 1: determination to do something that you have decided to do, even if this is difficult
will.translation[1].note_box[0].sections: a strong will
She had a very strong will and a clear sense of purpose.
an indomitable will
The indomitable will of the people remains the core strength of democracy.
a weak will
It's a myth that people are fat because of a weak will.
an iron will
Her unassuming manner concealed an iron will.
political will
There was a lack of political will to do anything about global warming.
strength of will
She had achieved success by sheer strength of will.
an effort of will
With a great effort of will, she resisted the temptation to look at the letter.
a battle/clash/test of wills
Even the smallest decision could become an exhausting battle of wills.
have the will to do something
Do you have the will to win?
lack the will to do something
He lacked the will to resist.
lose the will to do something
The country's troops had lost the will to fight.
will.translation[1].note_box[1].heading: – Meaning 2: a legal document that says who you want your money and property to be given to after you die
will.translation[1].note_box[1].sections: It is always advisable to make a will.
Who will inherit my property if I don't leave a will?
Marius had decided to change his will in her favour.
cut somebody out of your will
His father cut her out of his will.
If the estate is small, you may not need to prove the will.
Her eldest son is the executor of her will.
will.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to try to make something happen by thinking about it very hard
will.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: She was willing herself not to cry.
will.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: to officially give something that you own to someone else after you die
will.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: a legal document that says who you want your money and property to be given to when you die
will.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: They found a lawyer to draft their wills.
This is the last will and testament of John Smith.
will.translation[4].definitions[0].defin: to leave something to someone in your will
